Comparison of the claim to the actual go: The expert examines the claim made by Senator Rubio that the goal of the Affordable Care Act was to get 30 million people insured. They compare this claim to the actual goal of the ACA, which was to increase the number of insured individuals, without specifying a specific target number.
Analysis of the number of people insured: The expert analyzes the number of people who have signed up for health insurance under the ACA marketplaces since they opened in October 2013. They highlight that 7.1 million Americans have enrolled, which contradicts Rubio's claim that only 7 million people have signed up.
Evaluation of the Congressional Budget O: s estimates: The expert refers to the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office's estimates of the ACA's effects. They mention that the CBO estimated 7 million people would sign up on the marketplaces by March 31, 2014, and projected that by 2019, 27 million people would have signed up. This information provides context and supports the argument that the ACA is not falling woefully short of its goals.
Consideration of factors influencing the: The expert acknowledges that not everyone will end up with health insurance due to various reasons, such as undocumented workers being ineligible to shop on the marketplaces and states deciding not to expand Medicaid. They also mention the hardship exemption, which allows certain individuals to have the penalty fee waived for not purchasing insurance. This information helps to explain the potential reasons for the remaining uninsured population.
